name: Seven Come Eleven (7-11) Quiz | Corporations | 10 Questions

questions.text: In what year did the 7-Eleven chain start?
questions.explanation:
1927.

	A Southland Ice Company employee started selling milk, eggs and bread from the ice dock from 7 AM to 11 PM.

questions.text: How many stores did 7-Eleven have in the United States and Canada have in 2001? More than______?
Approximately how many gallons of milk (in millions) does the chain sell each year?
questions.explanation:
40.

	Last count was 41 million gallons per year which is enough to pour more than 2 glasses for every man, woman and child in the United States.

questions.text: Which state has the most 7-Eleven stores?
questions.explanation:
California.

	It has close to 1200 at the time of this writing. Texas didn't win this one.

questions.text: What area leads in the sale of hot dogs at 7-Eleven stores?
questions.explanation:
Washington DC.

	The Detroit area leads in the sale of Slurpees and the Las Vegas area leads in the sale of Big Gulp drinks, in the United States.

questions.text: 7-Eleven had the first TV ad of any convenience store. What two animals were involved?
questions.explanation:
Owl and Rooster.

	It first ran in 1949 and featured a singing owl and rooster.

questions.text: Which of the following was NOT a first for the 7-Eleven chain?
options: Fresh brewed coffee in "to go" cups
questions.explanation:
Banking services.

	They were also the first to sell pre paid phone cards and have a self service soda fountain.

questions.text: The 7-Eleven chain has the largest ATM network of any retailer in the United States?
questions.explanation:
True.

	Although it doesn't offer full banking services it offers you a place to get cash.

questions.text: A typical 7-Eleven store would carry about how many different items?
questions.explanation:
2500.

	Their stores average about 2400 and 3000 square feet which means they have quite a variety for their size.

questions.text: In what year did 7-Eleven coin the term "brain freeze"?
questions.explanation:
1994.

	To communicate the painful joy of drinking a frozen Slurpee beverage.
